name: (2E)-{5-[(E)-(4-fluorophenyl)diazenyl]-4-methyl-1,3-thiazol-2-yl}{[3-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl]hydrazono}ethanenitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-992

name: (2E)-{5-[(E)-(4-fluorophenyl)diazenyl]-4-methyl-1,3-thiazol-2-yl}{[3-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl]hydrazono}ethanenitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-992
Reason: The target compound has multiple functional groups that influence its melting point. Basic unit 1,3-thiazole typically has a melting point around 120°C. Each phenyl group: +30°C (due to the increased rigidity and π-π interactions). Fluorine atoms: +5°C for each fluorine due to the electronegativity and the increase in intermolecular forces (van der Waals) it provides. Nitrile group (C#N): +10 due to its linear shape and electronegativity. Hydrazono group: +15 due to additional nitrogen double bond providing more rigidity. Summing up the contributions, 120 (base) + 60 (2 phenyl groups) + 15 (three fluorine atoms on one phenyl) + 5 (one fluorine on the other phenyl) + 10 (nitrile group) + 15 (hydrazono group) = 225°C.
